title: Garth Hill
text:
Garth Hill (usually called The Garth, or Garth Mountain, "Mynydd y Garth" in Welsh) is a <a href="Marilyn%20%28geography%29">hill</a> located in between the communities of <a href="Llantwit%20Fardre">Llantwit Fardre</a> and <a href="Pentyrch">Pentyrch</a> in <a href="Wales">Wales</a>. The Garth can be seen from nearly the whole of the city of <a href="Cardiff">Cardiff</a> and the <a href="Taff%20Valley">Taff Valley</a>, and on a sunny, clear day as far as <a href="Weston-super-Mare">Weston-super-Mare</a> across the <a href="Bristol%20Channel">Bristol Channel</a> in southwest England. It lies adjacent to the <a href="River%20Taff">Taff Vale</a> with the village of <a href="Pentyrch">Pentyrch</a> on one side and looks down onto the small villages of <a href="Gwaelod-y-Garth">Gwaelod-y-Garth</a> and <a href="Taff%27s%20Well">Taff's Well</a>. The Garth has a number of <a href="tumuli">tumuli</a> on its top. These are burial sites dating from the early to middle <a href="Bronze%20Age">Bronze Age</a>.
Fine views of Cardiff and the Taff valley are obtained from the prominent crag.
The Garth has a sister hill, the Lesser Garth. The Lesser Garth is of <a href="limestone">limestone</a>, which is extensively quarried with much of the hill removed; it was also formerly mined for <a href="iron%20ore">iron ore</a>. The valley between the two is eroded in softer <a href="coal">coal</a> measures, shales in the main, while the Garth is formed of the resistant <a href="Pennant%20Measures">Pennant sandstone</a> formation.
Until the 19th century, the valley and the lower slopes of the Garth facing Taff's Well were full of small <a href="coal%20mine">coal mine</a>s which fed the <a href="ironworks">ironworks</a> below in the <a href="River%20Taff">River Taff</a> valley, opposite <a href="Taff%27s%20Well">Taff's Well</a>. There is now little trace of these although "Y Lan Colliery" has recently had its portal partly restored as a memorial to an explosion in 1875. A cleared path now leads to this, near the primary school. The access road to Pentyrch village, Heol Goch, runs between the main and lesser Garth.
<a href="Christopher%20Monger">Christopher Monger</a>, a native of Taff's Well, wrote the novel "<a href="The%20Englishman%20who%20Went%20up%20a%20Hill%20but%20Came%20down%20a%20Mountain">The Englishman who Went up a Hill but Came down a Mountain</a>". The location of the fictional "Ffynnon Garw" above the <a href="writer%27s%20home">writer's home</a> <a href="village">village</a> suggests that it is the Garth and the mound on which the <a href="Triangulation%20station">trigonometrical point</a> stands is a Bronze Age <a href="burial%20mound">burial mound</a>. Monger adapted the story for the 1995 <a href="The%20Englishman%20who%20Went%20up%20a%20Hill%20but%20Came%20down%20a%20Mountain">film of the same title</a> on which he was the <a href="Film%20director">director</a>. The popularity of the film has resulted in a stream of visitors climbing to the summit of Garth Mountain to view the location.
